results.title: A Pocketful of Rye
results.creator_credit: George Gallaccio, Guy Slater and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Miss Marple Series”.
In this sinister tale, set in the 1940’s, Miss Marple sets about unravelling the mysterious murder of city financier, Rex Fortesque. When the cause of death is identified as poisoning, suspicion falls on the occupants of the family home, Yew Tree Lodge. But the police are perplexed as the only clue to the murder is a handful of rye in the dead man’s pocket. However, when another murder shortens the life of suspects, the connection with the nursery rhyme “Sing a Song of Sixpence” is all too clear to Miss Marple.

results.title: A Pocketful of history
results.creator_credit: Crawford Productions, Bank of New South Wales, Ian Jones and Doug Tainsh
results.brief_description: The history of Australia is reflected in its various changes of currency. The story is told ful1 circle, from the first decimal coins, Spanish dollars, used in early Sydney, through the beginning of the Bank of New South Wales, the Gold Rush, Federation, Depression, two World Wars and finally the Decimal Currency Commission of 1959. Highlights include Ned Kelly’s daring robberies; opening of the first Parliament in 1910. Narrated by Roland Strong.

results.title: A Plea for the wanderer
results.creator_credit: Jean-Marc Garand, ONF | NFB and Jean Coutu
results.brief_description: From river to sea, and back to river again, this film follows the arduous life cycles of east and west coast salmon, revealing both the perils of nature and the threats posed by man. Vivid close-ups capture exciting moments when the salmon hatch, jump rapids, and perform their intricate spawning ritual. Other footage examines the Canadian government’s programs to protect the salmon runs. The film makes it clear that the continuation of indiscriminate high-seas salmon fishing could prove fatal to one of the world’s most important food and industrial resources.

results.title: A Planter of colonial Virginia (1740-1765)
results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Produced in collaboration with the Williamsburg Restoration, this film aims at an authentic portrayal of life in 18th century colonial Virginia. Williamsburg was the centre of the economic, social and political life of the colony, which depended mainly on the products of the tobacco plantations in the area for its wealth. The life of the slaves and indentured servants is studied, in conjunction with the current legal system, together with the social customs of the plantation owners and their families, and the music, architecture, and costumes of the period. The methods of manufacture, means of transport, and the medical practices of the day are also presented.

results.title: A Plain and sacred right (A)
results.creator_credit: David M. Thompson, ABC-TV (Australia) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Encounters”.
Looks at why Aboriginal people feel so strongly about their struggle for land rights. Filmed mainly at Noonkanbah, the scene of bitter Aboriginal demonstrations of 1980, the program looks at what Aboriginal people are now doing to preserve their traditional way of life. Tribal Aboriginals explain their bond with the land and put their views on white society.

results.title: A Place to work
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Rank Organisation, M.J. Clark and W. J. Allen
results.brief_description: Part of the “Patterns of living” series. Looks at Luxembourg’s iron and steel industry, Danish ship-building, Scottish fish processing, Swiss watch making and British car assembly to demonstrate the range and complexity of factors affecting the location of modern manufacturing industries. Considers transport costs, industrial inertia, decline and regeneration of industry. Useful as a resource for studies relating to manufacturing locations. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: A Place to stand
results.brief_description: A letter-boxed single-screen version of this dynamic award-winning multiple projection presentation. Produced by the Province of Ontario, for their stand at Expo ‘67. Up to nine different projectors are used of varying shapes and styles to display the manifold virtues of Ontario’s agricultural, mining, manufacturing and maritime industries, before examining the environmental features and recreational possibilities.
